channel.title: Dandenong Ranges Arachnids
channel.description: All spiders, their eggs, webs, or nymphs found in the Dandenong Ranges area which includes the area from Police Paddocks to Upper Beaconsfield to Cockatoo to Mt Evelyn.

item.title: Hypoblemum villosum
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 9mm long. Mid-afternoon. Outer urban back yard.

item.title: Nyssus coloripes
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A very fast spider exploring old bleached timber in our back yard.

item.title: Maratus volans
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Near a stream in dappled light among leaf and twig litter.

item.title: Sandalodes superbus
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: These female Sandalodes superbus look very different to the males. Hunting for prey on the welcome sign within a local nature reserve. Possibly Australia's largest jumping spider they also show little fear of big creatures.

item.title: Deinopis subrufa
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Indoor. About 100mm legspan. Tried to get closeup of palps.

item.title: Araneidae spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 12mm body length. On flowers in local nature reserve. Suspected Cyclosa spp. Yet to search for species...

item.title: Dolophones spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 10mm across. With prey possibly dipteran. Excellent camouflage on this branch.

item.title: Cheiracanthium gracile
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Under lights. About 30mm long overall. ID thanks to Laurence Sanders.

item.title: Breda jovialis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Used to be called 'Breda jovialis' Estimated 10% of the prey size. Perfect attack site. Bite 'n hang on ! Found under pavilion eaves. Yet to search for prey ID Reminds me of the weasel on the woodpecker.

item.title: Dolophones spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Approximately 8mm body length. Interesting colours on this one with red cephalo-thorax and abdomen and yellow legs.

item.title: Eriophora pustulosa
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Body length about 20mm. In a public barbecue area in a local nature reserve. Wicks Reserve. E pustulosa seems highly variable and I just read an informative blog regarding females and appearance and disappearance of lobes !! http://spiderblogger.blogspot.com.au/2013/05/the-final-weeks-of-wonderful-garden-orb.html

item.title: Sidymella longipes
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Body length about 20mm. V shaped abdomen. Climbing among twigs and dense leaves of Kunzea.

item.title: Deliochus pulcher
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description:
Will somebody pull this wetsuit off please? About 12mm body length this spider is trying to shed an old skin with only the legs yet to be extricated. Pic 2 is correct orientation so gravity may be an important factor. Also interesting is the two retaining lines; one from the original abdomen and one from the new. Did the abdomen come out first and place another line before proceeding? On eucalyptus branches in a local nature reserve. Gilmour Park.
(need to add ' Deliochus pulcher ')

item.title: Philoponella congregabilis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A tiny mottled brown and grey spider, suspended in a delicate web beneath a lily leaf, immediately becomes a pyramidal lump when disturbed. Camouflage or mimicry of some sort? Approximately 10mm. Suburban back yard. Previously named Uloborus congregabilis. Common on Australias east coast. Quite variable in pattern and colour. As the name suggests these spiders appear communally forming many orb type webs attached to each other.

item.title: Thasyraea ornata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Scrawny spider with beady little eyes and a silly looking fringe. Approximately 30mm total length. Found inside suburban laundry room. This one is apparently an ambush spider and prefers to live on eucalyptus trees. Must have got lost. Do not confuse this species with 'Tibellus tenellus (Family Philodromidae). Most photos of Tibellus tenellus for Australia are probably wrongly IDed.

item.title: Euryopis splendens
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: 2-3mm long this spider displayed some strange behaviours. When running it was so fast I was sure it must be jumping or flying. When it stopped it always buried it's head into a tiny depression, raised it's abdomen and wrapped it's front legs over the other pairs and around the sides of it's abdomen. It would then hold that position for many minutes.

item.title: Ligonipes semitectus
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A couple of jumping spiders resembling the local bullants. One (♀?) is larger than the other. About 10mm long overall but it was hard to tell individual sizes. On a blade of Gahnia sp. (sword grass) in a local nature reserve. I realise now one is possibly devouring the other.

item.title: Stephanopis cambridgei
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Approximately 15mm overall this weird spider didn't move like most. It was slow, turning constantly, waving two pairs of fore legs very slowly, and definitely attracted to my torch light. Strong patterns of cream, black, brown and quite tubercular in parts. Short abdomen and large flattened cephalo-thorax. I think I can see eight eyes but tiny and well dispersed. Slowly exploring a wall in a very dark area of the local school late at night.

item.title: Mituliodon tarantulinus
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 35mm overall; big furry palps; attractive cream-grey-black-brown patterns on the thorax; some small spots on abdomen. Searching for prey on a stone wall at night.

item.title: Cheiracanthium gracile
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A tiny spider on the wall with orange-tan head and thorax and a mottled green abdomen. Eight eyes almost all the same size and in two even parallel rows. Approximately 12mm long. Suburban house back wall.

item.title: Breda jovialis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: This little jumping spider is always found in darker places like under bark and in the shadows around buildings. About 12mm long. This one is a male. Found under a 'deck' in an outer urban back yard. Used to be called 'Breda jovialis' but Breda is a Brazillian genus so now it is 'Ocrisiona jovialis'.

item.title: Dolophones ssp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A tricky little spider which I only noticed when it moved onto a green stem from a grey one. Strongly resembling a broken twig node it was about 8mm across it's body. On twigs of Acacia mearnsii. Dolophones sp.

item.title: Tamopsis spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Size 16mm including legs. Abdomen like a milky opal set in gold. Very alert and fast moving. Attracted to arthropod activity around lights at the local school.
